At Roche Medical electronics we had a Schlieren through an Aquarium tank ( round pinhole light with round black dot obturator) to a video camera: we could image the ultrasonic beam patterns emanating from (3-Lens) Cloverleaf fetal monitor transducers. The cast epoxy lenses sometimes were improperly bonded to the flat PZT crystals, and the Schlieren clearly showed black streaks in the conical “flashlight beam” pattern emitted from the ultrasonic lenses.
We also had a sound pressure force balance that had 90 degree corner (point-up) covered in ultrasound-absorbing rubber suspended in another tank from a microbalance. When the Ultrasonic transducer was aimed at the rubber corner, the milligram “force” created by the ultrasonic sound pressure (deflected at 45 degrees) was proportional to the milliwatts of ultrasonic energy emitted through the water. Bureau of Standards method based on the paper by my Manager (pronounced “Ya-niss”) Janis Ziedonis. In the early 1970s. Peter Bourdelle

Those pingpong balls aren't just flammable, they can be highly explosive when condensed properly. One of my friends came up with a recipe for starting solid rocket engines, which used a mix of smokeless powder, aluminium powder, potassium chlorate, and other dopants depending on his needs for the rocket at hand. When he was done making this concoction he'd coat a tiny section of unjacketed ignition wire with it while it's dissolved in acetone, then once that dried hard again, he'd coat it in several layers of ping pong ball dissolved in acetone as well. Competition ping pong balls are actually made using 100% nitrocellulose, which is the same active component of flash paper (just tissue paper dipped in nitric acid and dried), and also a significant component of smokeless powder along with nitroglycerine. He claims that if he doesn't coat it in nitrocellulose, the starter may detonate sometimes, but it's very inconsistent, so coating it in hard nitrocellulose keeps the pressure in long enough to ensure detonation 100% of the time. his rockets were pretty fantastic performance wise so I trust his knowledge. Pretty sure this is just a common thing home made rocket enthusiasts use since i've seen videos demonstrating similar techniques here on youtube with various recpies

Shadowgrams are much cheaper and simpler to set up (no expensive optics), and they also let you see transparent gas refraction differences. They work on a different principle, the change in brightness caused by convergence or divergence of light that results from refraction (as opposed to seeing path bending in one dimension also from refraction and detected by Schliren). A setup allowing both measurements to be superimposed and displayed in two colors would be killer.

For better projected images without blocking as much light, you can use a line array shadow mask in front of the light. Blocks only half instead of 90+% for the pin-hole. Then use a copy of the same line shadow mask instead of a knife edge (ie. multiple knife edges). Finally, add a lens where the camera would be, to focus the object (in front of the mirror) on the projection screen (garage door).
Here's a smaller setup (8"/203mm mirror) built with the above line shadow mask (printed with a laser printer onto transparency film):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m55pWVQqe7Y&list=PLYqfcJ8a-a87-EoilUUcqRSR_E95lAPHD&index=66&t=1s

Hi Derek. This might get lost in a sea of youtube comments, but nevertheless I have a suggestion for a sound-based Schlieren imaging experiment. I was wondering if it is possible to observe a 3D standing waves in air (or some other transparent medium). Standing wave will create a pressure differences, so theoretically we should be able to see with this technique the pressure gradients between nodes and antinodes. With proper set up we might see similar patterns as Chaldni patterns produced on a 2D plane. The technical realization will probably be a bit more difficult, but this was just a quick idea that crossed my mind.

Awesome. Here is something you can try to show how heat can expand the surface of the mirror. I am currently making a parabolic mirror for my DIY telescope. I am using a similar setup to test the surface texture and profile of my mirror. The instrument I am using is a knife edge tester, where the knife cuts the light source in half, and the returning light from the mirror is also cut in half with the same knife, precisely at its focal point. Then you can see the profile and surface of the mirror. place your finger on the mirror surface for a couple of seconds and the area will expand on a nano scale, but in the camera you will see a hill forming on the surface of the mirror due to the heat expansion of the glass.

Last time I made a comment that you can perform Schlieren in 2 dimensions instead of just one:
Use a color filter with 4 quadrants.
2, 1
3, 4

Quadrant 1: Magenta rgb(255,0,255)
Quadrant 2: Red rgb(255,0,0)
Quadrant 3: Black rgb(0,0,0)
Quadrant 4: Blue rgb(0,0,255)

After that you can take the red data for 1 dimension and the blue data for the second dimension.

Using an old fashioned newtonian telescope look at a star on a dark night, then adjust the focus to make the star fill the eyepiece. You will see all sorts of shimmering in the light. Then have someone hold their hand in front of the telescope and you will see a sharp silhouette of the hand and you can plainly see the heat coming from hand. Even someone's breath is plainly visible. This may also work with other telescopes but it I've only tried it with an old Edmund Scientific 6".  Another trick to make your imitation star is to use a shiny sphere like a Christmas tree decoration or a shiny ball bearing and shine a light at it  from an angle. The light will appear as a pinpoint on the sphere. A laser would also work on the sphere. Great video, thanks.

That way instead of the small differences in temperature or pressure resulting in a mostly binary effect (darker/lighter, green/purple) you could hopefully see the magnitude of the pressure difference as a greater shift through the color spectrum.
The helium balloon was a good example since the density put the light well within the green side, but there was nothing to really show just how far into the green filter it was.

This is a bit of a long shot, and would be immensely complicated to pull off, but what about the gas flow inside a transparent firearm suppressor (or silencer) in ultra slow motion? Just flat out suppressor flow is fascinating, and Destin of Smarter Every Day posted the first good footage of it to my knowledge. Somehow visualizing that supersonic/subsonic flow in greater detail, perhaps with high pressure air from say an airgun rather than a firearm, would be fascinating. The issues are two fold. The first is understanding what is actually happening through all the obscuring flame, unburned powder, and carbon inside a suppressor. The second is, of course, achieving a high enough frame rate to really begin to understand it.

My hypothesis on the sound one: You can't visualize it in this way. You'd need a microscopic version of the Schlieren to see some sounds and a much larger version to see others (not to mention you'd need considerable resolution), and seeing a shockwave isn't really the same thing since it's such an extreme case that it's not just a sound, it's an explosion moving faster than the compression/rarefaction rate of the air. (Also, shockwaves aren't that cool in this way since you can see them with the naked eye.) To visualize the sound of the human voice, for example, I'd expect you need a surface of at least 6meters for your lens, since the wavelength of the human voice is roughly ~1.6m at the small end of things, you'd want enough space to see a full compression and rarefaction of the air.

Experiment Proposal: Get a tone generator and figure out a good possible wavelength to match the size of your current setup. I'd expect the sound to be pretty high pitched. Crank the volume as high as absolutely possible. Get a much, much brighter and sharper light source and do everything to increase the contrast on the image as much as possible (tinfoil-ing out the windows for example.)

Please please please try three filters... cyan, magenta, and YELLOW. This is a balanced set of primary colors. I'd LOVE to see if it makes an improvement or change of any kind.

Here's a lengthy explanation. Red, green, and blue are the primaries used in most digital displays. RGB is in "rainbow order" (ROYGBIV) but, CMY is not. That's because the CMY colors are in order relative to the RGBs. Cyan is like anti-red, magenta like anti-green, and yellow like anti-blue. Shine red, green, and blue filtered light on the same spot and you will produce white light: remove just the red and it becomes cyan; remove only green and the spot becomes magenta; remove only the blue and it becomes yellow.

You can think of Red-Cyan, Green-Magenta, and Blue-Yellow as supplementary lights because each individual pair combines to make white light. Pairing supplementary filters or a light with its supplementary filter should produce a colorless "shadow". This is how projectors used to work. They had three lamps and three filters to produce three shadow images. Rear projection TVs utilized the same type of projection system. They combined a red shadow, green shadow, and blue shadow to produce one color image. In theory, the same could be done with RGB filters for Schlieren imaging but, the result would be much dimmer than CMY filters. A comparison would certainly be interesting.

The red, green, and blue primaries probably came about as a result of Newtons study of optics. CMYK is common in print media and, given the ordering of the letters, probably came about for that reason and ironically after color TV. This irony is because the idea of painting primaries probably dates back to the Italian Renaissance but, the primaries are most commonly taught in grade school as RYB, which is problematic. Yet, painters experimented with different palettes long before TV and even before Sir Isaac. They were most likely aware that cyan and magenta could be used to create colors that would be impossible without them.

Please feel free to correct any mistakes with experimentation and/or research.

Fun Fact for the Kiddos:
Did you know that computer screens used to be monochromatic with black and white (Macintosh), green and black (anything older), or red and black (rare old model calculators)... even when TV was in color?

(Dear e-ink, you've been using the wrong primaries for your solid state displays for years. That's why the technology hasn't taken off... because you need CMY pigments and can't produce enough colors as a consequence. Convert from RGB encoding should be a cake walk. Perhaps I'm wrong and you corrected this problem already. Or maybe you just don't know what you're shooting for with your primaries. I can explain. The world might see a quantum shift in tech again if you sort out your materials. There should be a way to do 3D glasses as well.)

Place a transparent tube with a loudspeaker / tuning fork at one end to produce standing waves at the resonant frequency of the tube. If you are shooting at 2000fps and willing to accept 5 frames per cycle, then you could film a 400Hz standing wave. At 400Hz, the wavelength would be 300/400 = 0.75 m. The fundamental standing wave will fit in something half this big, so 0.375m, which should be small enough to be observable in your setup.

Actually the reason the mirror is parabolic is because parabola is a shape defined as the locus of points in the plane that are equidistant from both the directrix (a line) and the focus (a point). One property that a parabola has is the reflective property, which means that if a parabola can reflect light, then light which enters it travelling parallel to the axis of symmetry is reflected to the focus. So if you create a light source located at the focus, this light will be travelling all in the same direction (in parallel paths). You can see this at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parabola

This is totally different from a sphere. A 3D equivalent of a parabola is a paraboloid, which is different from a sphere.

I think I know how you could cheat your way into showing sound waves. Use a speaker to output at a frequency close to your frame rate. Like in this video for example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uENITui5_jU
By using a high enough "shutter" speed, you should be able to see the waves, moving at a speed corresponding to difference in frequency. Now if the shutter speed is not fast enough, the traveling waves will smear and the contrast will fall. But there might be a way around that one: use stroboscopic light source instead of the shutter speed to get close to the speaker frequency. In this way you can integrate longer without losing contrast. You need 1 arduino, one speaker and 2 transistors (one for your flashlight, one for the speaker).
Standing waves would also work. Resonant cavities are always fun.

Schlieren are optical inhomogeneities in transparent material not necessarily visible to the human eye. Schlieren physics developed out of the need to produce high-quality lenses devoid of these inhomogeneities. These inhomogeneities are localized differences in optical path length that cause light deviation. This light deviation can produce localized brightening, darkening, or even color changes in an image, depending on which way the ray deviates.
